posts.body:
>>7fc21bcb-091f-4993-b8eb-7ae9f9e60e41
I think this is pretty good.
Make the content of the blacklists easily visible and make people able to look at the blacklisted posts if they're still seeded, so that people can moderate the moderator and warn each other if the moderator has gone rogue.
I think then moderators with clearly defined goals that people can opt into will naturally flourish.

>>93624ed7-a390-4004-8690-740a73f98ff1
I don't think that's a good idea, make regular torrents instead. The website is a fracture point which plain old torrents don't have. 
And unlike zeronet, with torrents, you can use the DHT, so you don't need to worry about trackers and the peer base is less likely to fracture.

posts.body:
>>f8eadd36-aac5-4813-889d-5bfb719091cd
Hey, posting .ogg files is broken.
They infinitely check or parse or whatever was the word for the thing 08chan does for every file you post.

>>77dac0a1-7300-4c02-9442-ca0fa36d4b58
Okay, process. When you post one or many ogg files they infinitely process.

>>8e8641a5-bdae-4797-879b-a7f8ea551583
>Did you enable it on the settings or just use some jurry rigged solution with torsocks or something? Also monitor your trackers, it's easy to reach 0 working trackers when using Tor for some reason.
Get an obfuscation bridge, the trackers are banning you for one reason or the other.
Quick guide for linux users:

>install obfs4proxy, it's on Gentoo's repositories at least, no idea about other distros
>go to this page: https://bridges.torproject.org/bridges?transport=obfs4
>solve the captcha
>you should be redirected to a page containing a text box which has a handful of lines of text starting with "obfs4" written in it
>open up /etc/tor/torrc with a text editor as root
>append to it the lines in this code box:
[code]# Bridge configuration.
UseBridges 1
ClientTransportPlugin obfs4 exec /usr/bin/obfs4proxy[/code]
>prepend each of the lines starting with "obfs4" that you got from the website with the word "Bridge " (including the space) and insert them into /etc/tor/torrc , just after the lines you have inserted. Example with a fake line follows:
[code]Bridge obfs4 111.111.111.111 127A5F9F6E618989163628163819EEFFB197F7BAC cert=zkn9hWDWcigTI9D5qFa+k2aKqiTzhFq29ahgk185/2ugha2WQ18817hGWFSUEHK32/6KqyZ3Fg iat-mode=0[/code]
>tell tor to reload its configuration or restart it, whatever is your init system's command to do it

>>c4872193-1e69-4e58-83d6-16499d691e1b
>>aca9ab4f-342e-4de7-886f-87db9599faa8
I'm here, friends.
I think the recent news article has spooked a few. But remain strong, and proxied.

>PLAYAN
MB Warband
>WATCHAN
Some porn MMDs with shameful fetishes
>LISTENAN
Music from the comfy thread
>READAN
Dungeon Meshi
>EATAN
Cooked ham
>DRINKAN
Milk
>FAPPAN
Some porn MMDs with shameful fetishes
>FEELAN
My mood keeps changing with good and bad thoughts about 08chan

What if muting others works as a sort of upvote/downvote system, perhaps even worse than reddit, because a post with no seeders disappears?
It's widely circulated that the majority of posts in an imageboard are bad. Let's assume that means there are more people making shit posts than people making good posts. That may not be the case but I'm talking what if. They are the majority, and they have a system where they can perhaps inflict something into a certain user. In actuality, the HTML/JS/whatever of the board is well seeded enough that every post will always have seeds, but what if people instinctively ignore certain posts because their pictures don't load so fast? It could "prioritize" a few posts by practical positivity/negativity shown towards it.
On 8chan we had the hide button, in here we have the mute button. Even in bad boards with IDs such as **Mark's /v/**, with a hide button you would at most hide/mute that person for a single thread and not know who they are the next time over. Newfags were already advocating people ignore or hide everything they don't like, but in here the equivalent function is stronger, and the damage could be even worse. Imagine the echochamber potential. Imagine being unable to self moderate a board because after 1 or 2 posts you're just talking to the wind, and will be for a while.
That's all a what if, so that's good.

Mark fucking stickied an e-sports dota stream, he spills his spaghetti in threads and then nukes the thread itself, every time you triggered a hotpocket you'd get your post history erased. We had threads where people were replying to nothing because half of the thread was nuked and the ones who were there before the nuke didn't even understand why their or other people's posts were deleted. A hotpocket once made a CS:GO thread then banned any dissenters. Threads that should be out were allowed, threads that should be left untouched remained. I'm talking basic bitch shit here, people playing gachashit. It was basically cuck/vg/. We got shilled by /leftypol/ in specific extremely heavily between 2017 and 2018 and nothing was done about it, I hear it was looked into in 2019 but I barely posted on the website.
/a/ is in a tipping point where they're almost SJWs. Their self cultivated hostility to 8chan at large has blown up now that they have their website and other boards are flooding into the meta thread. the current /a/ moderation has created that userbase, which can't even handle bants, the minimum requirement for posting on an imageboard. Shit talk an /a/non and It will become a contest for "who said what mean thing". Make a thread about classic anime and it gets shitposted to death, meanwhile every low budget seasonal isekai reaches the post limit and you do get banned for stirring anything on those threads.
You can't disagree with people on /pol/ or you get banned by the moderation or piled on by the userbase also created by the moderation.


Simultaneously, 08chan is immune to bad board moderation. I think moderation has made larger boards such as /v/, /a/, /pol/, and /b/ unusable. That doesn't mean moderation is bad, but it seems that for the boards responsible for most of the traffic on the website, it went wrong and essentially crippled those boards, because /v/ and /a/ on 8chan never had good moderation and it only got to new levels of bad over time, /pol/'s moderation degenerated and killed it very quickly, /b/ is an exception moderation-wise in that it's really not the board that should be moderated to begin with, but dysnomia did it, and it was bad. Whatever happens here, the community is guilty of it. No moderators but ourselves to blame. 
There's hope, unlike previously, since it seems bad moderators also have a tendency to want to squat on their position. Here we make our destiny and after we do that we see if we're good at it.

I like the idea behind zeronet. If we can get this working well, and retain an userbase, then we have a small barrier of entry that will keep a portion of people who shouldn't be here anyway out while simultaneously aiding with the stability of this place and being more resilient to being taken down.
The post quality has been great, people just saying whatever comes to mind, a sense of community is there, the website owner has shown good ethic.
I also like 8chan's owners, whatever complaints people had of them, they allowed us to have our free speech spot and dedicated their lives to it. Hotwheels was secretly gathering information on his users, and Jim had the whole /newsplus/ debacle. The last one is forgivable I'd say, and hotwheels is not related to 8chan anymore, so I think we went rather well unless I don't know about something horrible.

>>b6d4b045-3b74-42fa-8e8e-40c37de05a1a
That last part was meant to say I like 8chan's owners, who gave us our free speech zone and fought for it.

>>d96ddf37-b463-4f1e-9384-945a52d7bcd0
I got sued for hate speech once, had dynamic IP.
Turns out they charged me for a "crime" I was guilty of, but by accident. They had a list of owners of a particular dynamic IP, no information other than those people used that IP and Facebook claimed someone who went through the IP was talking shit. I only used facebook in 2007 for like 10 posts. This was in the mid 2010s.
The list was of people who had gone through that IP, it had nothing else, and I happened to be on the top.
This wasn't in the US though, so I don't know how it is for muricafags

>>da22480f-e4b0-403a-b0bb-f0ea155cb3eb
IP hashing means the hotpockets can't see IPs. That's still stupid because you can hash the entire ipv4 range very quickly and then compare 8chan hashes with the ip -> hash database you can create in seconds.
On 8chan, instead of seeing the IP of someone who they banned, hotpockets see the hash instead.
Mark, who's the website owner, still can. I was told he's the only hotpocket there currently so I'm not sure, but if that's true then it means nothing because he doesn't even have to go through the non-effort..

>>78b00677-6ddf-4cd1-b3db-0be160541621
There's one detail though.
Nobody really knows who started what post.
When you make a post you say "this certificate said this" and forward it to other peers.
Those peers then forward the message of "this certificate said this" to other peers, and that cycle repeats itself indefinitely.
Obviously, the owner of the cert is the first person to do it. But how do you know exactly who's the first?
 
I advise everyone to keep good OPSEC, but it's not that much of an issue, and I've only discussed the terms of acquiring proof of someone making a shitpost in a deep web video game discussion blog, doing something about it is a whole different deal.

>>2a557f15-7513-4de0-892d-001308c9e36b

>>2d560ea1-6ad3-44d6-91f1-c889a0ae342c

>>da9984da-7d54-4c57-9b9b-c74608ab8b32
>most popular download is "Epstein Files"
Beautiful place.
I still think ipfs is the way to go since it has more robust sharing, even if all the implementations currently out are shit, and it doesn't solve the problem of actually finding that content. If we get a torrent-style client that just works, then we're set with ipfs.

I'm thinking a place that's like zeroup but the downloads are ipfs multihashes, ipfs is built such that if anyone is willing to implement it then zeronet can be one of the backends through which ipfs shares files, so the current zeroup could even be "upgraded" to ipfs one day, through peers with zeronet-able ipfs daemons that will share with other networks. The website itself could remain on zeronet if ipfs is not practical for website hosting.
>decentralized website for decentralized file sharing with built in filesearching
Make sure you have a privacy solution when browsing any of these, including 08chan itself. The media kikes are after us.

>>b94b5551-d258-4eac-ae58-b0e03bcb2d06
I'm thinking most issues people have with content, barring the zeroid cert thing are because they're on tor* and guard nodes ban p2p users.
Otherwise I'd say a captcha to counter spam and a method to have a cert per post automagically and I think we have a baseline of perfection to expand on.

*don't actually disable tor unless you have a VPN, cianiggers are datamining this place

>>3da076b6-2820-461c-91a1-a29119298673
>go to http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeroid.bit
>get a cert
>drag to the left the zero on the top right
>scroll down until you see the "identity address" line
>click change
>select the one signed @zeroid.bit
Posting should work then. That's necessary to avoid spam currently.
